unnormalised: Okay, so I remember when I first started learning differential calculus. It was during my 1st year engineering at IIT Delhi, and frankly, I was quite intimidated. The Prof, Dr. Sharma, was explaining concepts like dy/dx and limits, and it all seemed like abstract symbols. I mean, what even *is* a derivative, right?
normalised: Okay, so I remember when I first started learning differential calculus. It was during my first year engineering at I-I-T Delhi, and frankly, I was quite intimidated. The Professor, Doctor Sharma, was explaining concepts like d y divided by d x and limits, and it all seemed like abstract symbols. I mean, what even is a derivative, right?

unnormalised: Then, during a tutorial, a senior bhai explained it to me with a real-life example. Imagine you're driving your scooty from Delhi to Jaipur, a distance of roughly 280 km. Your speed isn't constant; you might be going 60 kmph on the highway, then slow down to 20 kmph in the city. Differential calculus helps you find your *instantaneous* speed at, say, exactly 2:15 PM. That 'instantaneous speed' is essentially the derivative.
normalised: Then, during a tutorial, a senior bhai explained it to me with a real life example. Imagine you're driving your scooty from Delhi to Jaipur, a distance of roughly two hundred and eighty kilometer. Your speed isn't constant; you might be going sixty kilometer per hour on the highway, then slow down to twenty kilometer per hour in the city. Differential calculus helps you find your instantaneous speed at, say, exactly two fifteen P-M. That 'instantaneous speed' is essentially the derivative.

unnormalised: The concept of limits was also tricky. The prof wrote something like lim (h->0) [f(x+h)-f(x)]/h on the board. It looked scary! But the bhai explained that it just means we're trying to find what happens to a function as we get *incredibly* close to a certain point, without actually reaching it. Think of it like trying to get to the last grain of sugar in your chai – you can get infinitesimally close, but you might not actually reach it if you are too lazy to scoop it out.

Think of it like trying to get to the last grain of sugar in your chai – you can get infinitesimally close, but you might not actually reach it if you are too lazy to scoop it out.

unnormalised: Once I understood these basic ideas, the rest of the course started making more sense. I started applying formulas like d/dx (x^n) = nx^(n-1) to solve actual problems. It wasn't just memorization; it was about understanding the *why* behind the *what*. Got a B+ on that exam eventually, definitely thanks to that chai-loving bhai!
